Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story:
My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was reviewing the patient’s chart. It was a text from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Call us when you can.” I glanced at the clock—Sunday evening. I hadn’t spoken to my parents all week, and guilt pricked at me. I knew they worried when I went silent, and I could almost hear my mother’s gentle voice, hoping for a few minutes of my time.

But in front of me, a patient was deteriorating fast. The infection was spreading, and I needed to decide on a course of powerful antibiotics, balancing risks and benefits, double-checking allergies, and coordinating with the pharmacy. Every second counted. My mind raced with medical protocols, but my heart tugged toward my family, the expectation to be present, to reassure them I was okay.

I stood in the harsh hospital light, torn between the urgent needs of my patient and the quiet, persistent love of my parents, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, demanding more than I could give at once.
